title: Git Basics
description: Essential Git commands for everyday development

cards.task: Set your Git identity for all repos
cards.answer: git config --global user.name "Your Name" && git config --global user.email "you@example.com"
cards.description: Configures your global author identity so commits on this machine are attributed to the correct name and email.
cards.whenToUse: Run once on a new machine or when you need to change the name/email attached to your commits.
scenarios: Fresh setup: New laptop that has Git installed but no author identity configured
Wrong metadata: Commits show the wrong email on GitHub and need to be corrected for future commits
Multiple emails: Switching from personal to work identity before contributing to a company repo

cards.task: Initialize a new repository with main as default branch
cards.description: Creates a new Git repository in the current directory and sets the default branch to main instead of master.
cards.whenToUse: Starting a brand-new project that isn't yet tracked by Git.
scenarios: New project kickoff: Turn an existing folder of code into a Git repo
Template cloning: After copying starter files without Git history, initialize clean tracking
Aligning naming: Ensuring the default branch is main to match GitHub's conventions

cards.description: Copies a remote repository (including commit history) to your local machine. Optionally rename the destination folder.
cards.whenToUse: Any time you need a local working copy of an existing GitHub repository.
scenarios: Joining a project: Pulling the team repo to start contributing
Code review locally: Cloning a fork to run the code yourself
Mirroring: Creating a local mirror before migrating repos between orgs

cards.task: Check the working tree status quickly
cards.description: Shows a short, branch-aware summary of staged, unstaged, and untracked changes.
cards.whenToUse: Before committing or stashing to see exactly what will be included.
scenarios: Pre-commit review: Confirm only the intended files are staged
Dirty workspace check: Ensure working tree is clean before switching branches
CI failure triage: Verify local state matches expected changes

cards.task: Stage files for the next commit
cards.description: Moves selected changes into the staging area so they are included in the next commit.
cards.whenToUse: After editing files and before running git commit.
scenarios: Selective staging: Add only the files that belong to the current feature
Partial work: Stage one directory at a time to keep commits focused
Fixup: Stage a single file to amend or supplement the previous commit

cards.task: Create a commit with a message
cards.description: Records the staged snapshot in the repository with a descriptive message.
cards.whenToUse: Whenever you want to capture a logical unit of work in history.
scenarios: Feature work: Commit after completing a discrete piece of functionality
Bug fixes: Capture the exact change that resolves a specific issue
Checkpoint: Save progress before pulling in upstream changes

cards.task: Connect a local repo to GitHub
cards.description: Registers the GitHub repository URL as the origin remote so you can push and pull.
cards.whenToUse: After git init when you're ready to sync the repo to GitHub.
scenarios: First push: Hooking up a new local project to a freshly created GitHub repo
Changing remotes: Pointing an existing local repo at a new organization URL
Fork workflow: Setting origin to your fork before pushing branches

cards.task: Push the default branch and set upstream
cards.description: Uploads the main branch to GitHub and records origin/main as the upstream for future pulls and pushes.
cards.whenToUse: The first time you push main from a new local repository.
scenarios: Project publish: Making the repository visible to collaborators on GitHub
Upstream tracking: Enabling simple git pull and git push without extra arguments
CI trigger: Pushing main to kick off GitHub Actions or other pipelines

cards.task: Pull the latest changes while keeping your commits on top
cards.description: Fetches upstream changes and rebases your local commits on top to keep a linear history.
cards.whenToUse: Before pushing your work to avoid merge commits and reduce conflict noise.
scenarios: Team updates: Syncing with teammates' changes before opening a pull request
CI failures: Rebase onto the latest main to pick up fixes before retrying
Conflict avoidance: Keeping a clean history for easier code review

cards.task: View a compact, annotated commit history
cards.description: Shows a condensed commit log with branch pointers and a text-based graph of the DAG.
cards.whenToUse: When you need to understand branch structure or recent activity quickly.
scenarios: Review prep: Check what's been merged before starting new work
Debugging: Visualize where a branch diverged from main
Release planning: See tags and branch tips to decide what's ready to ship
